trans-unit.source: Two-Class Locally Deep Support Vector Machine
trans-unit.target: Two-Class Locally Deep Support Vector Machine

trans-unit.source: Creates a binary classification model using the locally deep Support Vector Machine algorithm
trans-unit.target: Creates a binary classification model using the locally deep Support Vector Machine algorithm

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="0D90DCAB-08E1-4A66-9EA1-B571C22AE74D" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Machine Learning / Initialize Model / Classification</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="0D90DCAB-08E1-4A66-9EA1-B571C22AE74D" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Machine Learning / Initialize Model / Classification</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Two-Class Locally Deep Support Vector Machine</ui> module to create a two-class, non-linear support vector machines (SVM) classifier that is optimized for efficient prediction.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Two-Class Locally Deep Support Vector Machine</ui> module to create a two-class, non-linear support vector machines (SVM) classifier that is optimized for efficient prediction.

trans-unit.source: SVMs are an extremely popular and well-researched class of supervised learning models, which can be used in linear and non-linear classification tasks.
trans-unit.target: SVMs are an extremely popular and well-researched class of supervised learning models, which can be used in linear and non-linear classification tasks.

trans-unit.source: Recent research has focused on ways to optimize these models to efficiently scale to larger training sets.
trans-unit.target: Recent research has focused on ways to optimize these models to efficiently scale to larger training sets.

trans-unit.source: In this implementation from Microsoft Research, the kernel function that is used for mapping data points to feature space is specifically designed to reduce the time needed for training while maintaining most of the classification accuracy.
trans-unit.target: In this implementation from Microsoft Research, the kernel function that is used for mapping data points to feature space is specifically designed to reduce the time needed for training while maintaining most of the classification accuracy.

trans-unit.source: This model is a supervised learning method, and therefore requires a <newTerm>tagged dataset</newTerm>, which includes a label column.
trans-unit.target: This model is a supervised learning method, and therefore requires a <newTerm>tagged dataset</newTerm>, which includes a label column.

trans-unit.source: You can train the model by providing the model and the tagged dataset as an input to <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> or <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link>.
trans-unit.target: You can train the model by providing the model and the tagged dataset as an input to <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> or <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link>.

trans-unit.source: The trained model can then be used to predict values for the new input examples.
trans-unit.target: The trained model can then be used to predict values for the new input examples.

trans-unit.source: How to Configure an LD-SVM Model
trans-unit.target: How to Configure an LD-SVM Model

trans-unit.source: Specify how you want the model to be trained, by setting the <ui>Create trainer mode</ui> option.
trans-unit.target: Specify how you want the model to be trained, by setting the <ui>Create trainer mode</ui> option.

trans-unit.source: Single Parameter
trans-unit.target: Single Parameter

trans-unit.source: If you know how you want to configure the SVM model, you can provide a specific set of values as arguments.
trans-unit.target: If you know how you want to configure the SVM model, you can provide a specific set of values as arguments.

trans-unit.source: You might have learned these values by experimentation or received them as guidance.
trans-unit.target: You might have learned these values by experimentation or received them as guidance.

trans-unit.source: Parameter Range
trans-unit.target: Parameter Range

trans-unit.source: If you are not sure of the best parameters, you can find the optimal parameters by specifying multiple values and using a parameter sweep to find the optimal configuration.
trans-unit.target: If you are not sure of the best parameters, you can find the optimal parameters by specifying multiple values and using a parameter sweep to find the optimal configuration.

trans-unit.source: <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link> will iterate over all possible combinations of the settings you provided and determine the combination of settings that produces the optimal results.
trans-unit.target: <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link> will iterate over all possible combinations of the settings you provided and determine the combination of settings that produces the optimal results.

trans-unit.source: Continue to set other parameters that affect the behavior of the SVM model, such as the depth of the tree and lambda values.
trans-unit.target: Continue to set other parameters that affect the behavior of the SVM model, such as the depth of the tree and lambda values.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Options" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Options</legacyLink> section for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Options" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Options</legacyLink> section for details.

trans-unit.source: If you set the <ui>Create trainer mode</ui> option to <ui>Single Parameter</ui>, add a tagged dataset and train the model by using the <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> module.
trans-unit.target: If you set the <ui>Create trainer mode</ui> option to <ui>Single Parameter</ui>, add a tagged dataset and train the model by using the <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> module.

trans-unit.source: If you set the <ui>Create trainer mode</ui> option to <ui>Parameter Range</ui>, add a tagged dataset and train the model using <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link>.
trans-unit.target: If you set the <ui>Create trainer mode</ui> option to <ui>Parameter Range</ui>, add a tagged dataset and train the model using <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link>.

trans-unit.source: You can use the model trained using those parameters, or you can make a note of the parameter settings to use when configuring a learner.
trans-unit.target: You can use the model trained using those parameters, or you can make a note of the parameter settings to use when configuring a learner.

trans-unit.source: Locally-Deep SVM Options
trans-unit.target: Locally-Deep SVM Options

trans-unit.source: You can optimize the behavior of the algorithm by setting the following parameters:
trans-unit.target: You can optimize the behavior of the algorithm by setting the following parameters:

trans-unit.source: Create trainer mode
trans-unit.target: Create trainer mode

trans-unit.source: Choose the method used for configuring and training the model:
trans-unit.target: Choose the method used for configuring and training the model:

trans-unit.source: Single Parameter
trans-unit.target: Single Parameter

trans-unit.source: Select this option to configure and train the model with a single set of parameter values that you supply.
trans-unit.target: Select this option to configure and train the model with a single set of parameter values that you supply.

trans-unit.source: If you choose this option, you should train the model by using the <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> module.
trans-unit.target: If you choose this option, you should train the model by using the <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> module.

trans-unit.source: Parameter Range
trans-unit.target: Parameter Range

trans-unit.source: Select this option to use the Range Builder and specify a range of possible values.
trans-unit.target: Select this option to use the Range Builder and specify a range of possible values.

trans-unit.source: You then train the model using a parameter sweep, to find the optimum configuration.
trans-unit.target: You then train the model using a parameter sweep, to find the optimum configuration.

trans-unit.source: If you pass a parameter range to <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link>, it will use only the first value in the parameter range list.
trans-unit.target: If you pass a parameter range to <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link>, it will use only the first value in the parameter range list.

trans-unit.source: If you pass a single set of parameter values to the <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Parameter sweep</link> module, when it expects a range of settings for each parameter, it ignores the values and using the default values for the learner.
trans-unit.target: If you pass a single set of parameter values to the <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Parameter sweep</link> module, when it expects a range of settings for each parameter, it ignores the values and using the default values for the learner.

trans-unit.source: If you select the <ui>Parameter Range</ui> option and enter a single value for any parameter, that single value you specified will be used throughout the sweep, even if other parameters change across a range of values.
trans-unit.target: If you select the <ui>Parameter Range</ui> option and enter a single value for any parameter, that single value you specified will be used throughout the sweep, even if other parameters change across a range of values.

trans-unit.source: Depth of the tree
trans-unit.target: Depth of the tree

trans-unit.source: Type an integer that determines the maximum depth of the tree that can be created by the local deep kernel learning SVM (LD-SVM) model.
trans-unit.target: Type an integer that determines the maximum depth of the tree that can be created by the local deep kernel learning SVM (LD-SVM) model.

trans-unit.source: The cost of training increases linearly with tree depth; therefore, choose an appropriate depth, depending on how much time you can afford to spend when building the model.
trans-unit.target: The cost of training increases linearly with tree depth; therefore, choose an appropriate depth, depending on how much time you can afford to spend when building the model.

trans-unit.source: Training time should roughly double as the depth is increased by one.
trans-unit.target: Training time should roughly double as the depth is increased by one.

trans-unit.source: Prediction accuracy should increase, reach a peak, and then decrease with increasing depth.
trans-unit.target: Prediction accuracy should increase, reach a peak, and then decrease with increasing depth.

trans-unit.source: Lambda W
trans-unit.target: Lambda W

trans-unit.source: Specify the weight given to the regularization term.
trans-unit.target: Specify the weight given to the regularization term.

trans-unit.source: Regularization restricts large value components in the trained classifier.
trans-unit.target: Regularization restricts large value components in the trained classifier.

trans-unit.source: When the number of samples is insufficient given the number of features, you can use L2 regularization to avoid overfitting.
trans-unit.target: When the number of samples is insufficient given the number of features, you can use L2 regularization to avoid overfitting.

trans-unit.source: Larger values for <ui>Lambda W</ui> mean that more emphasis will be placed on regularizing the classifier weights and less on the training-set classification error.
trans-unit.target: Larger values for <ui>Lambda W</ui> mean that more emphasis will be placed on regularizing the classifier weights and less on the training-set classification error.

trans-unit.source: If the default value (0.1) doesn’t work well, you should also try {0.0001, 0.001 and 0.01}.
trans-unit.target: If the default value (0.1) doesn’t work well, you should also try {0.0001, 0.001 and 0.01}.

trans-unit.source: Lambda Theta
trans-unit.target: Lambda Theta

trans-unit.source: Specify how much space should be left between a region boundary and the closest data point.
trans-unit.target: Specify how much space should be left between a region boundary and the closest data point.

trans-unit.source: This model works by partitioning the data space and feature space into regions.
trans-unit.target: This model works by partitioning the data space and feature space into regions.

trans-unit.source: When <ui>Lambda Theta</ui> is minimized in such a way that that region boundaries in the trained model are too close to the training data points, the model might yield a low training error, but a high test error, due to overfitting.
trans-unit.target: When <ui>Lambda Theta</ui> is minimized in such a way that that region boundaries in the trained model are too close to the training data points, the model might yield a low training error, but a high test error, due to overfitting.

trans-unit.source: To reduce the number of parameters that need to be validated, a good rule of thumb is to set <ui>Lambda Theta</ui> to one-tenth of the value that is used for <ui>Lambda W</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To reduce the number of parameters that need to be validated, a good rule of thumb is to set <ui>Lambda Theta</ui> to one-tenth of the value that is used for <ui>Lambda W</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Larger values mean that more emphasis will be put on preventing overfitting than on minimizing classification errors in the training set.
trans-unit.target: Larger values mean that more emphasis will be put on preventing overfitting than on minimizing classification errors in the training set.

trans-unit.source: If the default value (0.01) doesn’t work well, you should also try {0.0001, 0.001 and 0.1}.
trans-unit.target: If the default value (0.01) doesn’t work well, you should also try {0.0001, 0.001 and 0.1}.

trans-unit.source: Lambda Theta Prime
trans-unit.target: Lambda Theta Prime

trans-unit.source: Type a value to control the amount of curvature that is allowed in decision boundaries in the model.
trans-unit.target: Type a value to control the amount of curvature that is allowed in decision boundaries in the model.

trans-unit.source: Larger values will give the model the flexibility to learn curved decision boundaries, while smaller values might constrain the decision boundaries to more of a stepwise linear pattern.
trans-unit.target: Larger values will give the model the flexibility to learn curved decision boundaries, while smaller values might constrain the decision boundaries to more of a stepwise linear pattern.

trans-unit.source: This parameter works in conjunction with the <ui>Sigma</ui> parameter.
trans-unit.target: This parameter works in conjunction with the <ui>Sigma</ui> parameter.

trans-unit.source: To reduce the number of parameters that need to be validated, a good rule of thumb is to set <ui>Lambda Theta Prime</ui> to one-tenth the value of <ui>Lambda W</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To reduce the number of parameters that need to be validated, a good rule of thumb is to set <ui>Lambda Theta Prime</ui> to one-tenth the value of <ui>Lambda W</ui>.

trans-unit.source: If the default value (0.01) doesn’t work well, you should also try {0.0001, 0.001 and 0.1,}.
trans-unit.target: If the default value (0.01) doesn’t work well, you should also try {0.0001, 0.001 and 0.1,}.

trans-unit.source: Sigma sharpness
trans-unit.target: Sigma sharpness

trans-unit.source: Type a value to use for the scaling parameter <math>σ</math>.
trans-unit.target: Type a value to use for the scaling parameter <math>σ</math>.

trans-unit.source: Larger values mean that the tanh in local kernel <math>Θ</math> (theta) is saturated, whereas a smaller value implies a more linear operating range for theta.
trans-unit.target: Larger values mean that the tanh in local kernel <math>Θ</math> (theta) is saturated, whereas a smaller value implies a more linear operating range for theta.

trans-unit.source: You can find the full optimization formulas in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Notes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section.
trans-unit.target: You can find the full optimization formulas in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Notes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section.

trans-unit.source: If the default value (1) does not work well, you can also try {0.1, 0.01, 0.001}.
trans-unit.target: If the default value (1) does not work well, you can also try {0.1, 0.01, 0.001}.

trans-unit.source: Number of iterations
trans-unit.target: Number of iterations

trans-unit.source: Specify the number of times that the algorithm updates the classifier parameters by using a random subset of examples.
trans-unit.target: Specify the number of times that the algorithm updates the classifier parameters by using a random subset of examples.

trans-unit.source: Feature normalizer
trans-unit.target: Feature normalizer

trans-unit.source: Choose the method that is used for feature normalization, or use no normalization.
trans-unit.target: Choose the method that is used for feature normalization, or use no normalization.

trans-unit.source: The following feature normalization methods are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following feature normalization methods are supported:

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Binning normalizer</ui></legacyItalic>: The binning normalizer creates bins of equal size, and then normalizes every value in each bin to be divided by the total number of bins.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Binning normalizer</ui></legacyItalic>: The binning normalizer creates bins of equal size, and then normalizes every value in each bin to be divided by the total number of bins.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Gaussian normalizer</ui></legacyItalic>: The Gaussian normalizer rescales the values of each feature to have mean 0 and variance 1.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Gaussian normalizer</ui></legacyItalic>: The Gaussian normalizer rescales the values of each feature to have mean 0 and variance 1.

trans-unit.source: This is done by computing the mean and the variance of each feature, and then, for each instance, subtracting the mean value and dividing by the square root of the variance (the standard deviation).
trans-unit.target: This is done by computing the mean and the variance of each feature, and then, for each instance, subtracting the mean value and dividing by the square root of the variance (the standard deviation).

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Min-max normalizer</ui></legacyItalic>: The min-max normalizer linearly rescales every feature to the [0,1] interval.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Min-max normalizer</ui></legacyItalic>: The min-max normalizer linearly rescales every feature to the [0,1] interval.

trans-unit.source: Rescaling to the [0,1] interval is done by shifting the values of each feature so that the minimal value is 0, and then dividing by the new maximal value (which is the difference between the original maximal and minimal values).
trans-unit.target: Rescaling to the [0,1] interval is done by shifting the values of each feature so that the minimal value is 0, and then dividing by the new maximal value (which is the difference between the original maximal and minimal values).

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Do not normalize</ui></legacyItalic>: No normalization is performed.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Do not normalize</ui></legacyItalic>: No normalization is performed.

trans-unit.source: Random number seed
trans-unit.target: Random number seed

trans-unit.source: Type a value to use as a seed if you want to ensure reproducibility across runs.
trans-unit.target: Type a value to use as a seed if you want to ensure reproducibility across runs.

trans-unit.source: Allow unknown categorical levels
trans-unit.target: Allow unknown categorical levels

trans-unit.source: Select this option to create a group for unknown values in the testing or validation sets.
trans-unit.target: Select this option to create a group for unknown values in the testing or validation sets.

trans-unit.source: If you deselect it, the model can accept only the values that are contained in the training data.
trans-unit.target: If you deselect it, the model can accept only the values that are contained in the training data.

trans-unit.source: In the former case, the model might be less precise for known values, but it can provide better predictions for new (unknown) values.
trans-unit.target: In the former case, the model might be less precise for known values, but it can provide better predictions for new (unknown) values.

trans-unit.source: Recommendations
trans-unit.target: Recommendations

trans-unit.source: This LD-SVM classifier is most useful under the following conditions:
trans-unit.target: This LD-SVM classifier is most useful under the following conditions:

trans-unit.source: You have a binary classification issue, or you can reduce your issue to a binary classification task.
trans-unit.target: You have a binary classification issue, or you can reduce your issue to a binary classification task.

trans-unit.source: You tried a linear classifier, but it did not perform well.
trans-unit.target: You tried a linear classifier, but it did not perform well.

trans-unit.source: You tried a non-linear SVM or other classifier, and got good classification accuracy, but it took too long to train the model.
trans-unit.target: You tried a non-linear SVM or other classifier, and got good classification accuracy, but it took too long to train the model.

trans-unit.source: You can afford to sacrifice prediction accuracy to reduce training time.
trans-unit.target: You can afford to sacrifice prediction accuracy to reduce training time.

trans-unit.source: LD-SVM models are a good choice when your data is complicated enough that linear models (such as logistic regression) perform poorly.
trans-unit.target: LD-SVM models are a good choice when your data is complicated enough that linear models (such as logistic regression) perform poorly.

trans-unit.source: LD-SVM models are also small enough to be used in mobile devices or other scenarios where complex models (such as neural networks) are too big to be consumed efficiently.
trans-unit.target: LD-SVM models are also small enough to be used in mobile devices or other scenarios where complex models (such as neural networks) are too big to be consumed efficiently.

trans-unit.source: Conversely, this model should not be used if you don’t care about model size or if a linear model is required for simplicity or prediction speed.
trans-unit.target: Conversely, this model should not be used if you don’t care about model size or if a linear model is required for simplicity or prediction speed.

trans-unit.source: There is also no point to changing to LD-SVM if linear classifiers are already giving good results or if you can get high classification accuracy by adding small amounts of non-linearity.
trans-unit.target: There is also no point to changing to LD-SVM if linear classifiers are already giving good results or if you can get high classification accuracy by adding small amounts of non-linearity.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: The LD-SVM model was developed by Microsoft Research as part of ongoing efforts to speed up non-linear SVM prediction.
trans-unit.target: The LD-SVM model was developed by Microsoft Research as part of ongoing efforts to speed up non-linear SVM prediction.

trans-unit.source: The work of Gonen and Alpaydin (2008) on the localized multiple kernel learning method was particularly valuable.
trans-unit.target: The work of Gonen and Alpaydin (2008) on the localized multiple kernel learning method was particularly valuable.

trans-unit.source: Use of a local kernel function enables the model to learn arbitrary local feature embeddings, including high-dimensional, sparse, and computationally deep features that introduce non-linearities into the model.
trans-unit.target: Use of a local kernel function enables the model to learn arbitrary local feature embeddings, including high-dimensional, sparse, and computationally deep features that introduce non-linearities into the model.

trans-unit.source: LD-SVM is faster than most other classifiers for several reasons:
trans-unit.target: LD-SVM is faster than most other classifiers for several reasons:

trans-unit.source: The model learns decision boundaries that are locally linear.
trans-unit.target: The model learns decision boundaries that are locally linear.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, a test point can be efficiently classified by testing it against its local decision boundary, rather than testing against the entire set of decision boundaries all over feature space.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, a test point can be efficiently classified by testing it against its local decision boundary, rather than testing against the entire set of decision boundaries all over feature space.

trans-unit.source: The model uses efficient primal-based routines to optimize the space of tree-structured local feature embeddings that scale to large training sets with more than half a million training points.
trans-unit.target: The model uses efficient primal-based routines to optimize the space of tree-structured local feature embeddings that scale to large training sets with more than half a million training points.

trans-unit.source: The cost of testing a point against its local decision boundary is logarithmic in the number of training points.
trans-unit.target: The cost of testing a point against its local decision boundary is logarithmic in the number of training points.

trans-unit.source: As a consequence of these optimizations, training the LD-SVM model is exponentially faster than training traditional SVM models.
trans-unit.target: As a consequence of these optimizations, training the LD-SVM model is exponentially faster than training traditional SVM models.

trans-unit.source: Optimization formula
trans-unit.target: Optimization formula

trans-unit.source: Research
trans-unit.target: Research

trans-unit.source: For more details, see <externalLink><linkText>Local Deep Kernel Learning for Efficient Non-linear SVM Prediction</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=511662</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more details, see <externalLink><linkText>Local Deep Kernel Learning for Efficient Non-linear SVM Prediction</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=511662</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Lambda W
